Title: Linking forum posts - GlobalWarming-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
1. what if the Epsilon value is in between 0 and 1 ? what kind of object is that called? 2.why the real temperature of venus is so high? is this because of the much higher quantity of green house gases or something else. 3.if the assumed glass in the climate model is a selective infrared black body then why it allow all the infrared energy to pass through( though in small energy). it would have absorbed the IR whole and hence no E*sigma*(Tsuffix a)^2 .
Upvotes:
0
#3 '...why it allow all the infrared energy to pass through?' It doesn't allow it to pass through. It absorbs all of it (increasing its temperature). But, since it is an infra-red black body, it (re)emits black body radiation in both directions according to the formula E*sigma*(Tsuffix a)^2 .
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Amit, I'm glad you're asking questions about the material. I'll try to answer them below. 1. As far as I know, there is no special name for an object with an albedo between 0 and 1. 2. Your question relates to the two-layer model in the 'Solve Your First Climate Model' homework, if that is something you're looking at. Venus' atmosphere is about 100 times more dense than Earth's, and it is 97% CO2. So, if you were to try to model Venus' atmosphere with a simple pane-of-glass model, you'd probably want to include more than 1 or 2 panes of glass. The video just shows the results for 1 pane of glass. The homework will show you how adding more panes of glass affects the surface temperature. 3. I'm not quite sure I understand this question. The glass doesn't allow any IR energy to pass through. It absorbs all IR from the Earth. Because it is a blackbody, it emits its own IR radiation, but in 2 directions - up and down. All blackbodies emit IR radiation if their temperature is above 0 K. Hope this helps! Feel free to ask further questions.

Title: Linking forum posts - GlobalWarming-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
In the simple climate model described during this week's lectures, each 'pane of glass' absorbs 100% of the radiation from the layer below. How realistic is this? And how significant is the amount (if there is any) of radiation from the ground that escapes directly?
Upvotes:
1
In the real world the light bounce a part, because the light 'IN' is UV, IR and visible. When the 'pane of glass' is thick are more bounce. The pane of glass or greenhouse is formed with a lot of gas (H2O, CO,CO2,O2,O3,Ar,NOx, etc)
Upvotes:
0
Hi Matthew, can't you really wait for the classes ahead? ;-) http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/EnergyBalance/
Upvotes:
2
Splendid!
Upvotes:
0
Francois's link is very good. The short answer is that it isn't very realistic. A significant amount of radiation escapes directly into space. How all this works is, I believe, the subject of Week 2.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Folks, Looks like a great discussion happening here. One thing I'd like to add, and I think this relates to what Gustavo was getting at: the approximation that the panes of glass are transparent in one sense (i.e., they let sunlight in) and opaque in another (i.e. they absorb 100% of the radiation from the layer below) arises from the kind of light we are considering. Most of the light from the sun is visible light, to which the pane is transparent, and most of the light (radiation) from the Earth is in the IR range, to which the pane is not transparent. The sun does emit some IR radiation, and the pane of glass would absorb that as well, but in our approximation we are neglecting that. Hope this helps!
Instructor's post : Hi Folks, Looks like a great discussion happening here. Most of the light from the sun is visible light, to which the pane is transparent, and most of the light (radiation) from the Earth is in the IR range, to which the pane is not transparent. The sun does emit some IR radiation, and the pane of glass would absorb that as well, but in our approximation we are neglecting that. Hope this helps!

The sun does emit some IR radiation, and the pane of glass would absorb that as well, but in our approximation we are neglecting that. Hope this helps!
Upvotes:
1

Title: Linking forum posts - GlobalWarming-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
In the simple climate model described during this week's lectures, each 'pane of glass' absorbs 100% of the radiation from the layer below. How realistic is this? And how significant is the amount (if there is any) of radiation from the ground that escapes directly?
Upvotes:
1
In the real world the light bounce a part, because the light 'IN' is UV, IR and visible. When the 'pane of glass' is thick are more bounce. The pane of glass or greenhouse is formed with a lot of gas (H2O, CO,CO2,O2,O3,Ar,NOx, etc)
Upvotes:
0
Hi Matthew, can't you really wait for the classes ahead? ;-) http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/EnergyBalance/
Upvotes:
2

Upvotes:
0
Francois's link is very good. The short answer is that it isn't very realistic. A significant amount of radiation escapes directly into space. How all this works is, I believe, the subject of Week 2.

Input.threadtitle: Question: Am I free to share Prof. David Archer's short talks and lectures ?
Input.posts:
I found the course very inspiring and practical, I would like to share some or all of the lecture videos with a small group of climate interested people on Face-book, that I am a co-editor for. Do I have permission to copy and share the lecture links from Coursera (I also found them on a site called Kaltura, although it appears to have been deactivated recently). I do not wish to violate any copyright infringements.

Instructor's Post
Hi Robert, This should be fine, as Coursera is free and open to the public. Glad you enjoyed the course!
